title: No Man's Sky Ship with Lights

description.text:
Seriously updated No Man's Sky ship with LED's at the front,, back and battery/switch compartments

Electronic Parts are readily available from eBay;

Battery clips;
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/10-Pairs-20Pcs-Spring-Battery-Contact-Plate-Replacement-For-AA-AAA-Batteries-/222514259745?hash=item33cee22721

Switch
8x8x13 DPDT latching
http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/5-Pcs-Square-8x8x13mm-6-Pin-DPDT-Mini-Push-Button-Self-locking-ON-OFF-Switch-/232209396353?hash=item3610c23281:g:XLQAAOSw9GhYfnUr

LED's
2 x 2.5mm (white) & 1 x 5mm (blue/white/red or whatever!)

Batteries
2 x AG13 (LR44) 1.5V

Printer Brand:

Duplicator 4X

Printer:

Wanhao

Resolution:

0.2-0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Create a 3D printed spaceship with basic wiring, switch, batteries and LED's This small project will inspire students to;
  • Print a complex model with a high degree of success (supports etc.. provided)
  • Allow them to wire and assemble a basic circuit
  • Require relatively fine soldering skills
  • Work out a step-by-step means of assembly

Lesson Plan Requirements: 3D printer and software (Repetier, Simplify3D, Slic3r etc..) Lesson 1
  • Introduction - Bringing virtual reaility into reality (Inspire with NMS video)
  • Navigate to this model in Thingiverse and download to computer. Final model should look like attached STL file.
  • Highlight supports and layout of model (why are supports required? etc..)
  • Ideally printed in PLA (explain filament differences etc..)
  • Layout models in 3D software, set printer settings etc..
  • Print model
    • Lesson 2 & 3
  • Hand out printed models
  • Careful removal of supports and parts (hood, landing gear and stand)
  • Tidying up of model - cleaning rough edges, making sure parts fit etc..
  • Paint if necessary using acrylic paints and fixers
  • Prep for next lesson - lighting it up!
    • Lesson 4 & 5
  • Overview of basic circuit diagram and components (example finished model)
  • Work out what needs assembly first, soldering and other considerations (e.g. extra length of wire etc..)
  • Soldering of LED's and switches, battery tabs etc..
  • Testing and appraisal

Material requirements
  • PLA filament (white 1.75mm)
  • Acrylic paints and fixers
  • 2x 2.5mm white LEDs
  • 1x 5mm blue/white LED
  • 1x 8x8x13mm DPDT push switch
  • 2x LR44 1.5V batteries
  • 2 colour wire reels (red/black)
  • Soldering iron, solder

• 3D printing
  • Painting
  • Soldering
  • Basic electronics
  • Assembly
  • 3D printer setup
  • Circuitry
5 hours (excluding print times)

description.text: This is a cool looking lamp made of some basic materials i had laying around. Its a greate project for learnig the absolute basics of electronics.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Doesn't Matter

Yes

Infill:

10%

Notes:

i Added a little to many supports so i wasnt able to remove them properly.

3D-Printer and filament
LED-strip
12V Powersupply (depending on the LED-strip)
Switch 
Soldering Iron/Solder'
Some leftover 0.5 cm thik plexiglass

• Basic wiring
  • Difference AC and DC
  • paralell/series
  • physics of light
Have the base/ all the bases pre-printed for the lesson. Also bring all the requierments.

Step 1

Print the base, if your printer is too small, i have also included the base sliced in half.

Step 2

Assemble the electronics. You want to cut the LED-strip so that it is 19cm long. Solder it to the switch, and make sure that the posetive and negative is right. Then connect the other end of the switch to the powersupply.

Step 3

Make the plexigalss ready. this can be in any shape and size you want. just make shure it fits within the 0.5*19.5 cm gap in the printed base.

Step 4

Put the electronics in place. Glue the LED-strip along the opening for the plexiglass. Lead the wire thru the little hole at the back of the base.

Step 5

Insert the Plexiglss and youre done! Congratz!

title: Toyota 86, Subaru BRZ, Scion FR-S Coin Holder Console Tray
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a removable center console coin holder/organizer tray for the Toyota 86, Subaru BRZ, and Scion FR-S. The stock cup holders inside a covered armrest were useless to me so I invented this. It uses a commercial coin holder that fits in grooves for easy removal. The model is Custom Accessories 91116 Coin Holder, and costs a little over $5 on Amazon.

I printed it with PETG on a UM 2+ using a .06 nozzle and a print speed of 50 mm/s. I then painted the parts with one coat of filler primer and 4 or 5 coats of Plasti Dip. This comes out very tacky, so I sprinkled talcum powder over the whole thing and rinsed it off. This makes it much less sticky and much more 'rubbery'.

I made it with a frame to maximize the storage space after experimenting with various types of trays. It also used a lot less plastic and was much easier to print. The parts are all cut up for easy FDM printing.

When using PETG or ABS, glue the parts together with IPS Weld-On 3 Acrylic Plastic Cement available on Amazon or most hobby shops. This water thin cement will melt and fuse the plastic together.

Obviously you do not want to glue the tray to the frame, but I thought I'd mention that just in case. ;) Just glue the frame together, then the tray rim to the tray. The frame has little detents to help line up the posts. Note the position in the rendered images.

These are all of the parts printed in PETG. Lightly sand the edges to remove any printing burrs. Glue them as described, and let the glue dry for at least 30 min for a solid connection Ready for use as is or it can be painted. I applied some filler (green) to make the tray finish smooth. Paint with Plasti Dip if you want a rubbery finish.

EDIT:

I modified the design so that it is much easier to print, what you now have are pins that you can push into the holes I created in the house and then can be glued or press fit, and the Awning tops that can be glued on to the pins so that you can customize the house a little bit to how you see fit. These are the awning parts or if you can print the awning assembly as a whole you can do that too, I added that as well.

To build a complete house you will need:

x24 PINS

x11 Awnings

x1 House Planter Blank

You can paint each part individually as you see fit also!

I will add more modular parts to this thing so it is much more make it your own, coming soon: doors, attaching building planters, and more as I think of em/get bored at work.

title: TSB-25AXZ3 Side-Address Shock Isolated Saddle for BM-700 / BM-800

description.text:
This is a combination saddle and post for mounting a Transound TSB-25AXZ3 capsule in a generic Chinese microphone body (BM-700 / BM-800) for side-address use. It should print fine without additional support on most printers.

The mounting holes should match the holes in any of the BM-700 and BM-800 derivative microphones. The one caveat is that some of these microphones only have two of the four holes tapped in their upper plates. The holes are tapped to take M2.5 screws. This will work with only two screws, but if you decide to fully populate the mounting screws, be aware you may need to purchase a tap and tap handle in order to finish the job.

The mounting holes are designed to take shock isolating grommets used for RC servos. Du-Bro #115 "Natural Rubber Grommets for Small Servos" or equivalent work fine.

The stock screws that come with the donor mic will likely be too short to use with this mount because of the additional thickness of the grommets. I used M2.5x6mm screws with M2.5 washers to mount mine. This is the shortest screw I would consider.

For this mount, the wires run down a hole through the middle of the post. The hole is 3mm in diameter, so there's not a lot of room for wires. But you shouldn't need more than 3mm to get the job done. Neumann uses the equivalent of 30ga wire on their mics. I used 28ga and still had room to wiggle. The thinner and floppier the wire, the less microphonic coupling you'll get through the capsule wires.

Attach the capsule to the saddle using an adhesive like E6000.

This, like my other capsule posts/saddles is a labor of love for the mic building community. It's an effort to make the mechanical aspects of building microphones more approachable for those without full-blown machine shops at their disposal.

This was designed in Rhino3D using a model of the BM-700 / BM-800 microphone I reverse-engineered the first time I used one as a donor body for a DIY microphone.

description.text:
Add-on Duct for multirotor.

This is designed to add on to an existing multirotor or fixed wing with adequate space. This will mount between motors and frame arms with the props below the motors like a pusher motor in a plane.

Proportions and parameters based on the work of Jason L. Pereira [1].
First introduced to me by capolight [2].

[1] https://drive.google.com/file/d/0BzZ213vBQVkTOHFnbUxkRVRZOGc/view
[2] https://capolight.wordpress.com/2015/01/14/quadcopter-rotor-duct/

Notes:

I have not yet printed this because I do not have a printer with large enough print area.

I would suggest printing upside-down with the motor mount closest to the build plate. Also use very low infill with enough bottom layers for the spokes to be completely solid.
Any ridges left in the shape should be smoothed out however you would like. I would first attempt sanding but may try using a filler material first so as to not lose the desired blade tip clearance.

These are the parameters of this design as they are in the included STL file:

// set up for 5 inch propellers
propDiameter=127;
propHeight=5;

// duct sizing based on articles referenced above
ductInsideDiameter=propDiameter*1.002; // 0.1% of ID gap around prop
ductLipRadius=ductInsideDiameter*0.13; // 13% of ID
ductTailRadius=3;
ductDiffuserLength=ductInsideDiameter*0.6;
ductDiffuserFlareAngle=5;

// motor set up for Emax 2205 motors
motorDiameter=28;
motorHeight=17;
motorShaftClearanceDiameter=8;
motorScrewMinRadius=8;
motorScrewMaxRadius=9.5;
motorScrewClearanceHoleDiameter=3.15;
motorScrewCounterBoreDiameter=6.5;

motorMountThickness=4;
motorMountSpokeThickness=4;
motorMountSpokeCount=8;

author: JoPri

description.text:
OpenForge
=========
Crenelated wall tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Can be stacked on Stone Corridor Tiles or Stone Wall Tiles with Pillars to create defensive walls.
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Painting

Painting was done in 5 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges

comments.text: Stupid question: "What is the difference between 'crenelated wall' and 'edge crenelated wall'?"
comments.author: cyclone

comments.text: It's cool, the difference is not immediately obvious.  The non edge ones are a perfect match with Dwarven Forge, but the edge series was designed to give a bit more playable area, especially for 5' wide areas which are kinda unworkable with DF

description.text:
I made the holes for the screws thicker, as I was having issues with them snapping off too easy.

I recommend PETG as it's really good for "Snap Fit" parts. However, ABS should work just as good. PLA tends to sag over time, so I don't recommend it.

Use supports if the bridging doesn't come out as expected. Just be careful removing them.

Notes:

I recommend PETG as it's really good for "Snap Fit" parts. However, ABS should work just as good. PLA tends to sag over time, so I don't recommend it.

Use supports if the bridging doesn't come out as expected. Just be careful removing them.

Step 1

Clean up any loose filament that was made during the "bridging".

Step 2

Snap the chain pieces together.
You will need about 30 of them for the 3uP.

UPDATE: I added a new version "boo_supported.stl" that is designed to be printed at a 45 degree angle and has built in supports. With a well tuned printer this will result in the best quality for all faces. Give it a shot! The printed version in the photo was done this way.

OpenForge
=========
Crenelated edge corridor tiles designed to be compatible with Dwarven Forge dungeon tiles. Can be stacked on Stone Corridor Tiles or Stone Wall Tiles with Pillars to create two sided defensive walls.
These tiles are designed to line their wall up with walls from tiles butted up against their neighbors. These are designed to be used on the edge of the map or to give more usable space for the play area, particularly for 1x hallways which would be impossible to fit mins in unless the wall was moved. Because the wall now takes up some space, you will need to use edge buffers in some places to get the tiles to lay out properly.
You can find this set on github
OpenForge Sets
=============
  • Smooth Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc.
  • Smooth Edge Tile Series - Smooth tiles that can be used as concrete, dirt, ice, etc. Edge tiles.
  • Stone Tile Series - Stone tiles.
  • Stone Edge Tile Series - Stone edge tiles.
  • Crenelated Tile Series - Crenelated Tiles
  • Crenelated Edge Tile Series - Crenelated edge tiles
  • Tudor Tile Series - Tudor tiles.
  • Tudor Edge Tile Series - Tudor edge tiles.
  • Ruined Series - Ruined stone walls
  • Accessories - Pillars, etc.
  • Non-Series Tiles - Misc tiles, such as the pool
  • Module Specific Tiles - Tiles designed for specific modules.
    • OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our website, at our forums, or on twitter and facebook.
Painting

Painting was done in 5 layers.
  • Paint whole piece in black
  • Heavily dry brush with a dark grey
  • pick at least one other color (that could be stone) and paint some random stones, front and back.
  • dry brush with grey mixed with a little olive
  • lightly dry brush with a light grey, focusing most heavily on edges
    I paint the wall portion of the underside since it can be visible if the wall is stacked.

comments.text: The quality and sheer scope of this project is awesome.  It looks like the corridor STL's in this "Thing" are missing the crenelations - perhaps the wrong files got uploaded since they don't match the photos?  Regardless, thanks for the effort you've put into these.
comments.author: Hank-Cowdog

comments.text: Thanks for noticing that.  All fixed!

author: dankowski

title: Remixed Nerf Sight & dart holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed the original, but when the holders broke off as soon as i put the first dart in,
I attempted to I remix the stl file in Rhino3D to thicken up the "wings, but The source for this remix, itself a remix, appears to have been a mesh blend of their original source files. This left a lot of artifacts in stl file which made "fixing" it in Rhino rather difficult.
So i sketched up my own version using the source model as a reference, and this is the result.
It has slightly thicker "wings", and less surface details.

UPDATE 10-25-2017.

Due to the fact that I did not bevel the edges on the alignment blocks on the underside of the rail, it's difficult to remove once attached to your nerf gun.
Time permitting, I will revise the file to make those changes. In the interim, please print it knowing that it may not come off as easily as it should.

comments.text:
Sorry, when I made this to put it on my kid's nerf gun, I never considered whether or not it would be easy to take back off.
Since they're only 5 & 8, and they don't care much about being able to take it on-and-off on a regular basis; I figured that if they didn't break it 5 minutes after having it on there, then it's good enough.
comments.author: dingo

comments.text: Any recommendations on getting it off the tac rail?

title: Georgia Pacific - Push Paddle Roll Towel Dispenser 54338 - Clutch Gear

description.text:
Our paper towel dispensers broke at work and it took us a year to find out why.

The culprit was the gear surrounding the clutch that drives the roller and interfaces with the push paddle.

Simply remove the gear, push the metal clutch piece out of the gear and into a new gear.

title: Light-weight "Google Cardboard" VR glasses
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Update

Added 45mm focal length frame & various lens diameter frames (Haven't tried personally)
If you have size request - use comments

Description

This is an original design. I was aiming for a comfort, build stability and light weight.

Result print is very light (96g with textile and straps - for comparison Xiaomi VR play weighs over 250grams)

Lens diameter: 25m, Lens focal length: 40mm (added more dimensions)

Print is meant to be covered in thin textile. - That way VR goggles "can breathe" - no more sweaty forehead and foggy lenses. You can also add cushions to the forehead and nasal area. To prevent phone from slipping, just add a rubber band to the holder.

No supports needed:
PLA 1.75mm, 45-50 mm/s speed, 0.275mm / 0.25mm layer height
Print time ~4.5hrs, result weighs ~75grams

Easy to assemble / disassemble.
No screws / glue required
Ideally - everything will be held together by force.
Parts alone are wobbly and unstable, but when assembled and worn, opposite forces are applied making the construction firm.

SW Used

Dimensions inspired by Cardboard 1.0
Made with Sketchup Make + Booltools 2 + STL Export
Design time ~4 hours
STL optimization with 3D Builder by MS

comments.text: nice idea to get rid of the unnecessary plastic and replace it with cheaper/lighter material. trying to print one right now, lenses are ordered, will report back when done :)

description.text:
A bracket to hang my beach chairs. I have three on them currently.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/k0iRFk9AKcp

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

25

The perfect setting for you to relax as you make hollow threats upon the world. It's The Ryugyong Hotel in North Korea. Started about thirty years ago, the darn thing still isn't finished. That's communism for you. No money or motivation to get it done.

However, it is a beautiful building and a cool concept, and since I like to recreate unique buildings in CAD, this was a winner.

The dimensions are accurately scaled to the real thing, so if you happen to have a 3D printer 350 meters tall, and a spool of filament a few thousand kilometers in length, you can print a full scale model. And you'll probably finish sooner than Kim Jong's crew.

In my case, I only printed as high as my printer would allow, minus a centimeter or two. I think this one is 16.5 cm tall, but I'd have to go back and measure to be sure.

This model is based on the progress they had made as of 2005 (even though I made the model in 2016). I liked the look of it before they installed the windows.

Background: It was started in 1987 and is still unfinished as of this posting. Coincidentally, they just wasted more money firing a missile over Japan today. So I leave on this note: North Korea: Cool architecture, terrible leadership.

If I disappear after posting this project, you'll know who was behind my disappearance.

remixed_from.author: baschz
remixed_from.title: CR-10 Z-Axis Manual Adjustment Knob & Lead Screw Cover (Hictop, Tevo Tornado)

title: CR-10 Bigger Z-Axis Manual Adjustment Knob (Hictop, Tevo Tornado)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
#ZKNOB
This two piece part replaces and adds to the acrylic stock cover on the Creality CR-10's Z-axis lead screw; It lets you manually control the hot end up and down (when steppers are disabled), which I have found to be VERY handy at times. For example when you're loading filament, stopping a failing print or first layer, you can easily lift the hot end by hand to give you more working space and a better view of the piece.

Works exactly the same as the earlier version I made, just with a bigger knob. This way it takes less spinning to manually up and down the hotend. Easily fluently movable with just one finger. Cover plate is the same as in the original version.

VIDEOS
A simple quick and dirty demonstration by me of how the knob works:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=yPHjmhsJESk

And a more professional video by Chuck Hellebuyck on how to install the knob (and some other useful CR-10 (mini) mods) on Filament Friday: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qDG_C5y-psU&t=3m23s (3 minnutes and 23 seconds in).

UPDATES & HELPFUL COMMENTS

FIX (as of 02/10/2018)
Thanks to user wonkoderverstaendige I found out there was a tiny (but real) problem with the file. Basically the knob floated 0.002mm above the stem, which only caused a problem when sliced in particular way, but it had definitely a weak spot. So if yours snapped at any point, this is probably why. You should have no problems with the fixed file anymore. Sorry for the inconvenience if it got you frustrated!

10/28/2017
Pemic: "The knob works also for the Tevo Tornado. The stock cover is not necessary. To gain a little space on the upper side of the spindle, you have to pull the Z stepper axle a little it out of the coppler."

10/28/2017
Fort_Design: "I just wanted to let you know that this design will not fit the Anet E10. Mainly because the housing of the upper bearing on the E10 is closed on top. One would have to redesign these housings. Diameter of the spindle on Anet E10 is 8mm."

Printer:

Creality CR-10

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Print the knob upside down. No supports needed.

I used 3 perimiters and a 30% infill, but you could go higher for extra strength. I've been using mine on a daily basis for months now and I haven't had any problems yet.

Pictured parts are printed in Das Filament PLA at 210°C/50°C on the Creality CR-10.

Just swap the acrylic stock part with the freshly printed cover plate, using the stock screws. The knob then simply screws onto the lead screw until it's snug enough to let you control both up and down movements with it.

comments.text: Of course! Pretty new to all this myself as well :) Anyway. The lead screw that is the Z-axis was in my machine at least originally held in place on top with a black acrylic piece with a hole, but it had so much slack the lead screw could move quite a bit. I designed and printed a new cover plate and decided to also add a knob on top, so you can easily manually move the Z-axis and thus the hot end up and down, without having to go into the menu and do it from there. The version right here is the same idea as the first version I mentioned in the description, just with a bigger knob. It takes less effort to move up and down. Hope this answers your question, otherwise just ask again and I will try and explain it better :)
comments.author: abmhpd

comments.text: By the way the slack is important the point of the slack is to prevent any deviation of the Z axis screw from translating into your model if there is a slight wobble or misalignment in the z axis screw this will translate to a shift in your print in the vertical by allowing the z-axis to move slightly it can absorb this shift instead of transferring that shift into your model think of it like the suspension on your car the suspension absorbs some of the impact so you don't have to

description.text:
Inspired by the one and only (and very real) Thomas Crapper. No, he didn't invent the flush toilet, but he secured the patent for it (or something along those lines) in London back in the 1800s and began to sell them with great success. Some of Thomas Crapper's manhole covers are still in London to this day. His business lasted over a hundred years, was eventually sold in the 1960s and dissolved. But by the grace of the porcelain gods, the company is back again, selling fine bathroom fixtures for all to enjoy.

I decided to design my own toilet from scratch, using no drawings whatsoever. I can't speak for you, but in my particular case the bathroom is a place I visit several times per day. Therefore, it was quite easy working from mental notes.

This toilet can be printed in pieces and then superglued together. It would work great for holding paperclips on your desk, or perhaps some unwrapped chocolates.

Note, I cannot vouch for the functionality of this project. I never tested it.
This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://tinkercad.com/things/7jRSWrVAccD
I made a simple representation of a wind turbine and mast.

A food forming stamp inspired by this set: http://bit.ly/1blNILa (links to amazon.de) I ordered one example of this thing at shapeways and it works great (the small holes to allow excess fluid to go away are a bit small). Still no experience with home printers.

title: TEVO Little Monster LED COB Light Mounting Bracket

description.text:
Mounting bracket for mounting a 100mm LED COB light for car headlights. These were sold with the 12-24V current control so I could just plug them in parallel with the extruder fan, until I take the time to pass additional wiring to the extruder to allow separate LED control.

I got a set of two, which are mirror images of each other, hence the two LedRing STLs. These were sold as 100mm outer and 90mm inner diameter. The exact title was US 2X 100mm HID White 117 COB LED 12-24V Angel Eyes Halo Ring Fog Housing Lamp. It was a good deal for two and now I have a spare.

The stand offs give the ring about 20mm (3/4 in) clearance from the nozzle tip.

For simple wiring just connect them with the extruder fan. The LEDs come on when extruder starts warming up and turn off when the extruder cools down.

Revision

After staring at the printer with the lights on I decided the ring LEDs needs a lampshade. The side emission is too bright to look at for long periods of time.

I added a LedRingShroud.STL for a shroud that mounts on top of the ring, on posts for the support arms. The loops are only 0.5 mm thick and there is extra space between the support and the ring. After attaching the ring to the support arms with the screws the shroud is held firmly in place.

The shroud model is 11mm high. This will cover the full side of the LED assembly. If you want it shorter, simply stop printing at the desired height.

Printer:

TEVO Little Monster

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2 mm layer height

Infill:

varies by part

Notes:

Ring Base (1x)

  • 0.20 mm layer height
  • 50%-70% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 2 perimeter layers
  • no support
  • no raft

Support arms (3x)

  • 0.20 mm layer height
  • 30% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 2 perimeter layers
  • support only between the two skirts on the effector mount. You can safely delete the rest of the supports, they are not needed if your printer can handle 10mm bridging.
  • no raft

LED Shroud (Optional, 1x)

  • 0.20 mm layer height
  • 50% infill, 3 top, 3 bottom and 2 perimeter layers
  • no support
  • no raft

The shroud model is 11mm high. This will cover the full side of the LED assembly. If you want it shorter, simply stop printing at the desired height.

1. Snap off the little support on the wire strain relief. The STL has a 0.2mm gap between it and the tip of the strain relief clamp, so it should come off easily.

    Use ao knife to remove any left over support from the wire clamp.

  2. Clean up the holes for the 3 screws in both the ring bracket and the support arms. The screws can be any 5 mm long small screws.
Installation

The supports slide into the slot between the delta end mounts on the effector.

  1. Pass the wires from the LED ring through the hole in the base of the ring bracket

  2. Mount the LED ring on the ring base by snapping it into the slots of the base.

  3. Squeeze the wires under the strain relief clamp hook on the base.

  4. If you printed the shroud, put it over the ring base before attaching the supports

  5. Slide all the supports into their slots on the effector.

  6. Fit the ring base stubs into the supports and put 3 small screws to secure it.

  7. Wire the LED right to the extruder fan or any other means to supply them with power.
The camera cannot handle the contrast but in real life it is bright and clear everywhere around the printer.

I am new to 3D printing and find Fusion 360 to be the easiest to use when taking an idea to a working model.

I use parameterized dimensions to allow easy tweaking and reducing the model size for faster test prints.

In this case I went through 3 iterations of ring to nozzle clearance: 5 mm was a bit too close to the bed, 10 mm was getting in the way of seeing what was being printed. Settled on 20 mm as a compromise between having the LEDs out of the way high enough, yet low enough not to have the extruder body cast a shadow on the part being printed.

description.text: This is a foot for the Ultimaker 3D printer which has a long tubular support to contact flush against the recessed bottom of the machine for extra stability and strength. It has a semi-circular channel carved out to accommodate the wires from the stepper motors and printhead to the control board. This part is meant to be used in tandem with a rubber damper to reduce vibration and sound to the surface that the printer may be sitting on. This has a marked impact on reducing noise when printing on top of a wooden table. This design is loosely based on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17770 by Maurits. It is more inspired by the suggestion of Jaydmdigital on the page of: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14802

• Download "Strong Foot for Damper.stl"

title: Spooler for MendelMax - Remix with Support and Speed Holes

description.text:
My first MendelMax printed and used

MendelMax spool holder by Amplivibe

This worked extremely well, looked futuristic and fantastic, and was easy to print in PLA, with supports. However, it was a lengthy print, and not without its own challenges (tuning supports for the first time: the first set I printed were solid!).

Browsing around for an ABS compatible spool holder I could print for the MendelMax, I came across:

Spooler for Mendelmax by Lke

I loved its smaller, almost minimalist, style, and the 608 bearing races on the outside were a great way to ensure that the spool didn't unscrew itself and entangle the filament.

Inspired by my first spool holder, I decided to add aesthetic voids to this spool holder. I also added a fillet on the load-bearing portion of the bracket used to screw the holders to the frame, and also a support for the bearing races, designed for printing ABS with Slic3r to maintain a proper brim. The result is what I share with you.

It works pretty well, and is pretty nice to look at too!

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

A support has been provided in the one spot that requires it, if printing ABS with a brim. Slic3r does not like generating brims around an object, with support added. This works around that.

If your printer is well tuned, even with ABS that support should come out with just two fingers and a little nudge.

author: blackrice000

description.text:
I'm working on cleaning up my printer station and couldn't find a container for my RAMPS board that I liked, so I've designed this one. I haven't printed it yet so it most likely still needs tweaks. As soon as I finish printing my enclosure brackets I will be making this next.

I'm using an 80mm wide and 30mm deep fan for cooling the board.

The idea of the design is that the cables will come in through the large circle opening, can be wrapped around the pegs to shorten them, then run them through the gaps to the board itself. The fan cable is fed through the small hole in the corner of the fan guard, then through the hole in the lid. The latch on the right hand side is meant to go on first, then the one on the left (really not sure if that's going to work or not).

Because I'm building an enclosure I didn't design the mounts to attach to the frame of the printer but to the outside wall.

The only sections that should need support is on the fan guard depending on which side you print up, and possibly the latches on the container itself.

If anyone notices anything I got wrong, suggestions for changes, etc, please let me know! If you print one, let me know how it went!

author: nzfreemo

title: Titanfall Pilot Battery - Designed for Electronics
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Disclaimer: I haven't printed this out myself yet. I intend to. That said, I think it'll work.

This is designed to print a 1:1 scale Pilot battery from the game Titanfall 2. It has been broken into as many parts as I can reasonably manage to make the printing process a bit easier... or at least, so that it fits within the bounds of my Makergear M2 Printer.

This battery is designed to accommodate 120 5mm Green LEDs in total. The battery can be thought of in quadrants - divisions of four - with each side having 30 LEDs. Six of these are mounted behind the big inset circles, and 24 are mounted behind the smaller side discs. The parts are designed in such a way as to be printed individually, sanded, cleaned up, and then glued into place on the battery body. My plan is to then get some pieces of acrylic, cut them to fit behind each of the parts in front of each LED, and sand them to diffuse the light accordingly. The LEDs are all installed into printed strips that hold them in the correct positions and orientations. The strips themselves mount into holes or recesses designed onto the interior of the battery body.

You could totally just go ahead and use LED strip lighting on the inside instead of what I designed this for. Just stick it to the printed strips.

The bottom of the battery has a hollow chamber that I designed to be big enough to hopefully fit a few C-cell batteries in a battery holder. You could wire your LEDs straight to 2 C batteries, all in parallel, or you could use an arduino or other microcontroller to make the LEDs dim, glow, or otherwise animate. The bottom lid has holes sized for 4xM4 screws as an easy way of securing everything shut.

The handle has been designed in two separate pieces with a hollow channel on the inside. I figured I'd wire some kind of on/off switch onto the underside of the handle, but I didn't get too particular about it while designing this. You can always just grab a dremel and carve out a spot for a switch wherever you fancy.

Most if not all of the parts have small holes channeled through them. These are to aid in alignment during assembly. They've been sized for 1.5mm brass rod, which I have in abundance. Cut a bit of rod, glue it into a hole on one side, and you have a handy post to help you line up the other adjacent parts.

I left some holes in the barrel shroud in order for you to epoxy all the pieces together and secure it to the gun. Then you can switch between the A180 and P08 easily. If you love Airsoft and Star Wars these parts combine those two things plus it makes an excellent prop for comic con.
An Airsoft replica of a P08, Epoxy, Aluminum spray paint, Black spray paint, a file, Sand paper.
This is the reference I used to make this. http://tinyurl.com/y99u28rq

author: mikelucash

description.text:
Spent some time searching for a case for MTester I recieved as a gift and one for my dad but couldn't find any that fit the 91make one I received (there are a couple here on thingiverse), I didn't know at the time searching LCR-T4 instead of MTester would get me more hits, so I designed my own (or two)...

Two meters ordered in the same batch apparently can be very different... The boards look the same, however the component placement and mounting was a little different (as I found after printing 2 cases...)

If one of these doesn't fit, take at look at the others, you may find one that fits your device.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

100%

Notes:

All parts were printed in RepRapper PETG, 240C hotend, 90C bed.
The STL's have a couple of supports built in which was more than enough support on my printer, you may want to check the case back in your slicer prior to print if you know you have issues bridging. Infill was set to 100% simply as there were only 1 or 2 layers which would have had infill and with the thin walls its easier to print at 100%.

More info:
The firmware can be upgraded, more info:
https://forum.banggood.com/forum-topic-96675.html

More links on the device and firmware/upgrades:
https://www.mikrocontroller.net/topic/248078?page=6#3784106
https://www.mikrocontroller.net/articles/AVR_Transistortester#Downloads_.28English.29
https://www.mikrocontroller.net/svnbrowser/transistortester/
https://www.eevblog.com/forum/testgear/$20-lcr-esr-transistor-checker-project/950/

Build & Assembly Notes:

General:

  • Post printing remove the 2 rectangle supports from the Case Back (they should seperate fairly easily, there is at least 1 layer of separation to the internal back at .20mm layer height). Also remove the 2 tiny supports on the case front where the clip lip overhangs (front edge where the PC board shows through) else you might have a problem getting the board to fit.

Assembly:

  • Set the MTester straight in, making sure the button and IC socket pass through straight, watch the LCD ribbon, it may need to be "tucked" in between the lcd and board a little. Once its sitting down almost on the posts, pull the front edge forward slightly so the lip clip clears the board and the front drops in, then pull the back wall out slightly so the board drops below the 2 clips on the back side, this should lock the board in place securely.
  • Pass the 9V connector through the opening in the back diagonally, grab it with a pair of needle nose and pull it through.
  • Line up the front and back and snap together.
  • hook up the battery, push it in connector first and slid the door into place, snapping to close.
  • ...
  • Profit!

The parts below are required to thingy the "Whaaaaatsit?":
  • 1x either Case Front V1.stl or V2, check which one will fit your tester (if either)
  • 1x Case_Back.stl
  • 1x Battery_Door.stl
Revisioning:

v1.0 - Initial upload

title: Control Surface Hinges.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These can be used on any control surface, but are specifically designed to match My Concealed Aileron Linkage. The diameter of the hinge knuckle is identical to that of the Aileron linkage so you can easily maintain a even gap along the wing.

In the photos I have the hinges mounted on top of the wing, but they can be placed under the wing. If you use them under the wing in conjunction with the concealed aileron linkage, make sure the linkage and hinge knuckles are all on the same side of the wing.

Assembly:

  1. Take a brad nail and cut it to match the width of the hinge. A dremel is the easiest way, but I also trimmed a few with a old pair side cutters.

  2. Insert the nail head side out into the half of the hinge with the small square mark on it. ZThis half has a slightly larger hole to allow the hinge to pivot. DO NOT GLUE this part.

  3. Now put on the second half of the hinge. This side has a smaller hole and should be very tight. I used a small hammer to gently tap the nail into the second half of the hinge. Make sure you check that you are not over tightening the hinge. The first half from step 2 should pivot around the nail freely, but not have any horizontal slop.

  4. For extra precautions I add a drop of superglue to the end of the hinge where the nail is visible (not the head end).

  5. Let the super glue dry then use hot glue to connect to your control surfaces.

Note: I model knowing the limitations of my 3D printer. Its old and has a few minor quirks. In general its accurate but holes especially tend to print out smaller than they are sized in the model. As such I model holes slightly larger to accommodate this. Test print any part and make sure any attached hardware like wire or skewers fit properly before bulk printing.

title: Pumpkin Candy Dish
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a small-ish, 130mm wide candy dish that I made for Halloween. This is my first ever attempt at using Blender, so... be kind :)

-=[ UPDATE ]=-
I've made a couple of modifications. For starters, it turns out that the original bowl model was not manifold. I told you I was just learning blender :) So, I have corrected that and now [bowl-v2] is manifold. I have also added a new version of the lid - [lid-no_stem] - along with it's associated [stem] file. You can now print the lid and the stem as two separate entities to facilitate easier two color printing.

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1 - 0.3

Infill:

10%

Notes:

This needs [Supports Everywhere] turned on, especially for the lid. This will look best if you can print it in orange. Then, for the lid, you can pause the print as soon as the last layer of the pumpkin itself is printed and then switch to green filament. Slicing in Cura 2.6.1 at 0.3mm layer height, the pause was at layer 76, but your mileage may vary, so double check for yourself to be sure.

If you go with the [lid-no_stem] and [stem] files, you will need supports for both. Print the lid in orange and the stem in green. You may want to use a brim for the stem if adhesion is an issue.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/e1uaAR0moTt
Just cut the copying ring from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15186 since I have the original copying ring, but have lost what ever it was that was in the center.

The TACO i3+ was born out of the mindset of “bringing RepRap back to RepRap.”

An ever growing portion of the RepRap industry is currently developing machines with non-reproducible components such as factory-folded metal and injection molded parts. While this helps their bottom line and production timelines, it deviates from the original intent of RepRap, which was to allow a single printer the ability to reproduce a majority of the parts needed to build another.

While the overall market appears untroubled by these developments, these shifts hurt 3D printing's promises to tech education, print fulfilment, and the true mastery of 3D printing as an art. The community still needs truly open source machines that can be dissected, tinkered with, and easily modified. It still needs machines that grows as its operator grows in knowledge and capability, that can self-repair and foster the ability to do so, and most importantly, can be relied upon to produce beautiful prints time after time, 24/7.

In other words, the world still needs an up-to-date, fully open source workhorse.

That is exactly what MyOpen3D has built in 2017.

The design philosophy behind MyOpen3D's TACO i3+ 3D printer--a true RepRap synthesis of the Taz and Prusa i3 dev paths. It's all right there in the name:

T = Taz, naturally. Given the striking resemblance, it's clear there was no shortage of inspiration from the large format printer; from its solid aluminum extrusion frame to its 3D printed plastic parts, all meticulously redesigned for the TACO's smaller footprint.

AC = The initials of the founder of MyOpen3D and the TACO's lead developer. The TACO not only marries two of the best and renowned RepRap printers into one, but also benefits from thoughtful customizations born out of years of 3D printing experience. It’s more than a mashup, and its precise design is a testament to the design ethos of MyOpen3D and its founder.

O = "OMG," which we're confident everyone will when they see how well the TACO performs. It's stable, accurate, reliable, and fast. Very fast. (Besides, its name now spells "taco." Who doesn't like tacos?)

i3+ = Of course, we also owe credit to the Prusa i3 for establishing a widely-adopted form factor. The TACO i3+ is built to the same basic measurements of the Prusa i3 so that many of the innovations and mods developed by the community can be brought to the TACO i3+ with little or no modification.

Finally, our appreciation extends to the Printerbot LCv2 as well, which is the printer MyOpen3D cut its teeth on. There is little doubt that our time with the LCv2--a printer that, while heavily modified at this point, is still in service at the MyOpen3D Print farm--shaped aspects of the TACO i3+'s design.

Don't take our word for it, however. Build one and see it in action! Last but not least, if you're in the Pacific Northwest, look us up and reach out to us. We'd be happy to connect with other community members, whether it be for support or talking shop!

If you are interested in purchasing an DIY or fully assembled TACO i3+ printer directly from us at MyOpen3D, just contact us directly at [email protected]

Be sure to follow MyOpen3D for more fun projects and content on 3D printing, CNC milling, basic electronics and engineering!

https://www.myopen3D.com
https://www.facebook.com/myopen3d
https://www.instagram.com/myopen3d/
https://twitter.com/myopen3d

Key Parts

A few details till we get the full BOM up

Aluminum extrusion is 15 mm x 15 mm x 400mm (10 pcs)
Linear Rods are 8mm x 400mm (6 pcs)
M3 hardware Nuts & Washers, and most screws are 8mm long
M4 is used in just a few places.
M4 and M3 melt in brass inserts are used in numerous places for secure fixture points.

Electronics:
Designed around Arduino mega with ramps shield however the electronics plate could be easily adjusted for other packages.

9/15/2017 Update: I got it Printed, It turned out great (except for the stringing, which is my settings fault.) The model did what I hoped. I hope you enjoy. :)

author: nubeio

title: Wide Tooth Comb (cnc/laser)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The drawing of this comb was done in mere minutes. Hence this is a project to give you an idea on what is possible to do with a small desktop cnc. I took the geometry from a comb made from plastic that I really use a lot. The macassar veneer gives my version a unique and beautiful finish.

Using 2 mm (!) airplane plywood (3-ply) where glued on macassar veneer on both sides, resulting in a 5-layered piece of stock material. Then I cut the shape with my Stepcraft desktop cnc-machine and a spiral toothed 2 mm endmill. After cutting I sanded the teeth with a strip of sandpaper and finished the comb with a water based varnish.

As I don't have a 3d-printer I can not verify the usability of a print. Maybe someone could give it a try and show the result?

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Glueing on the veneer The glue needs to be spread out very thin and evenly. High pressure is more important than a lot of glue! The milling is a quick process. Just make sure to secure the material and use a end mill with 2 mm diameter (or less). A little sanding on the teeth and the comb is done.

author: frdd

description.text:
Another cobbled together model I made on Vectary.

I wasn't able to find a Froghemoth model anywhere online, so I figured I would make a version for my own games. Feel free to use this thing wherever you see fit!

Please share your LCD screenshot as "I Made One"!

NOTE: This is not supported by BCN3DR, and I have no affiliation with the company. This is a community supplied firmware, and is to be used at your own risk.

The BCN3DR is a nice entry level Delta printer, but now has 3 year old Marlin firmware, and BCN3D doesn't appear interested in supporting/developing the printer any further.

Upgraded firmware for BCN3DR to the latest Marlin. In practical terms, I ported the stock BCN3DR Marlin 1.0.x settings into Marlin 1.1.5 configuration.

UPDATE: Changed thermistor settings to 11, less thermal issues now.

Please report issues in the Github repo

Tip: If you have "thermal runaway" or "heating failed" error messages, up the values in THERMAL_PROTECTION & THERMAL_PROTECTION_HYSTERESIS in Configuration_adv.h. The stock firmware didn't have this feature, so there were no BCN3D supplied values to port over. Mine is at 60/10 and runs flawlessly.

P.S. The bezel profile STL supplied is simply so Thingiverse would allow publishing here.
Buckle for the Skip Hop Bag

This is a modular platform for the BCN3DR printer, which allows for mounting different hotends like the E3D V6. This is an attempt to bridge the gap between the 3DR Simple community and the BCN3DR printer community.
To select your hotend mount, look for any 3DR simple hotend mounts.

UPDATE: Mounted on the printer, I had to add a washer on each arm to make the 47mm spacing of the arms match up with the carriages/towers. Works perfectly!

Auto-leveling mount

This design includes the auto-leveling sensor mount, which is easily removed in the .scad file, as it is already configurable.

Fan mounting

I had to remove the fan mounting corners to make this fit the arm width of the BCN3DR (it is wider than the 3DR Simple due to the belt driven carriages). I simply used a fan system which mounts to the hotend, for which there are more compact options (i.e. saving bed space & avoiding tower impacts).

Credit to @darco for the great 3DR Simple design I tweaked in OpenSCAD. I am far from an expert in OpenSCAD, but it works ;)

title: X-Carve with Quiet Spindle - JTech Laser Middle Mount

description.text:
This is a custom laser cutter/engraver mount for the Quiet Spindle Holder in the X-Carve CNC Machine.

The laser head is built by JTechPhotonics. I use the 3.8 watt Version, but any head should fit (as of Sept/2017).

The mounting holes for the head are at about 2.0" from the work surface for enough clearance from the material to the collet. The beam focused perfectly within the factory recommended distance by fine tuning the Z-Axis.

title: Ikea Trådfri EU Light Switch Cover (Tradfri)

description.text:
Recently I have changed all lightbulb at my home to Ikea Trådfri. After this change I have left with two problems: where to put remotes when they are not used and how to prevent other people from turn off light using old switch. To solve both of this problems I have designed this cover that should be suitable for most of light switches over Europe. Now remotes for lights are in place of old light switch and everyone that is used to old way of turn off light is clicking them automatically.

Only thing that can't be printed and is required to hold remote is place is strong neodymium magnet 10mm diameter and 5mm height. In middle there is place prepared for it. It should easily fit in it and keep there firmly.

This model was optimized to print on 0.4mm nozzle. Also cover is mostly hallow so it require small amount of filament. My last print required only 5.5m of filament.

How to print this cover?

You can print this cover in two ways:

  • in standard way - this will require a lot of support structures, but finish will be great without additional post print processing, big problems are printing time (around 5h) and big waste of filament on support structures,
  • in upside down way - support structures are greatly reduced, they are required only in middle part, outside walls can be printed without it (had only problem with small warping of ABS during print), but finish will require additional sanding.

Both ways of print are visible on attached photo. Left cover was printed in standard way, when right one is printed in upside down mode with small sanding. I was thinking about smoothing finish using acetone vapor (print is in ABS).

title: x-carriage + mount for 5500 mW Laser & e3d v6

description.text:
Because I wanted to upgrade my printer to a laser cutter, I decided to re-design the x-carriage from dldesign to mount/dismount my e3d v6 or 5500 mW laser easily (links at the bottom).

I am also using an 12 mm diameter inductive sensor.

Also I wanted to increase the maximum building height so I shifted the hotend-mount to the top as much as possible.

I'm still using the same belt holder from the original design.

For assembling you will need:

  • 12 x M4 screws
  • 8 x M3 screws
  • 8 x M3 hex nuts

Original carriage:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2077676

Inductive sensor:
https://de.aliexpress.com/item/M12-4mm-detection-5VDC-NPN-NO-LJ12A3-4-Z-BX-5V-cylinder-inductive-proximity-sensor-switch/32553311139.html?spm=a2g0s.9042311.0.0.ctsBlO

5500 mW Laser:
https://www.banggood.com/445nm-5_5W-5500mW-Blue-Laser-Module-With-Heatsink-For-DIY-Laser-Cutter-Engraver-p-999283.html?rmmds=myorder

Getting Started (note: This video is NOT from myself, it should just explain the wiring):
https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=Q1KTGC1Dbz0

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

40
